ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to critically read/analyze Japanese poetry and form our own interpretations
The history and development of Japanese poetry as well as many aspects of its development. Additional practice writing types of essays that I was less acquainted with.
A historical and contextual understanding of Japanese poetry (waka) from the year 700ish to 1200ish, as well as knowledge of individual authors and collections, and different poetic movements.
History of Japanese poetry from 9th to 20th century. We read through waka to narrative poems to haiku. We also learnt about literary theories regarding the rhetorics of waka and intertextuality.
I learned a lot about Japanese poetry and culture from different eras and how it relates to and differs from Western poetry and my own conceptions about poetry.
Thinking critically and analysing poetry in translation.

Through this course I learned how to analyze and truly understand each of the poems to its fullest in relation to Japanese history and the historical events occurring at that time. This course allowed me to grasp the different concept accompanied with learning the different types of Japanese poetry and the influence modern Japanese culture obtained on each of the written poems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I really liked how the paper prompts were pretty open ended--allowed us to really focus on something we found interesting. I thought class time was effectively used to help interpret specific poems and learn about certain linguistic aspects that would have been difficult to pick up on for non-Japanese speakers like me. 

Weaknesses: Sometimes lectures were a bit disorganized and weekly readings were often hard to access. I would have liked to do a general overview at the very beginning of the semester of different Japanese poetic time periods (Heian, Buddhist Era, Meiji, etc) to help us contextualize all the content.
Faster grading wouldve been helpful (maybe it needs a TA next time?)  but it was overall a great course. Discussions / readings were always interesting and I found the essays satisfying to write.

Strengths: the content of the course is super interesting! It's something that I hadn't known anything about before taking the course, and I don't think anyone else in the class did either. The professor is super nice, and the classroom environment was really chill and comfortable and discussions were fun. The professor was really accommodating when we needed to ask for extensions. Weaknesses: We didn't get any feedback on any of our essays before the end of the semester (nor any grades at all), so it was hard/impossible to know if we were meeting the professor's expectations in the essays.

This class is very interesting and clear organized. The readings are well selected to keep up with the classs progress and are interesting to learn about. The workload is manageable, and Professor Scanlon-Canegata creates a comfortable class atmosphere that facilitates discussion.

The discussions were very enjoyable; the class had a great vibe. I also felt like everyones opinions were welcome. One thing that could be worked on is smoother accessibility to course content: it would be nice if every week was clearly outlined, perhaps in the modules folder on canvas. This is likely just due to the novelty of the course, though, so I have no doubts it will be resolved in future years.

Strengths: good teacher, good at lecturing, very interesting material.
Weaknesses: sometimes the reading assignments were confusingly laid out or difficult to find.

The strengths of this course was how quickly my professor responded to questions and how interactive the course was. He truly understood the difficulty of being a student at such an institution and provided words of comfort and encouragement. Many of his lessons were well thought out and captivating. The only weakness was the areas to find homework in which he improved the moment we addressed the issue!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Even if the course was disorganized, I thought the content and lectures themselves were super interesting. The papers allowed me to exercise my creativity. I had never read Japanese poetry or literature before, and this course definitely made me want to explore it more in my free time.
A very interesting course with a very low workload, cant do much better than that. Definitely take it if Prof. Scanlon-Canegata is teaching it again!
Yeah, I would! It was a fun, chill time, and if you're interested in the topic but don't know much about it, it's a cool course to explore Japanese poetry.

Yes. This class is suitable for people who wants to learn about the basics of Japanese poetry , even if they have no experience with the language. The class is well-taught and people can bring any thoughts about Japanese poetry, no matter if sophisticated, to the class discussion.
I would recommend this course to any student who wants to learn more about Japanese history and literature, or any student interested in poetry.
I would, if they are interested in poetry or Japanese culture or both, or if they're looking for something interesting that they don't have much experience with.
Yes I would recommend this course to another student who genuinely enjoys learning about Japanese history and is truly interested in Japanese culture as well as literature
The professor made this class really interesting and very engaging.

extras.title: EALL 236 01/EALL 536 01/LITR 181 01 - Japanese Poetry and Poetics TR
